trigger: The rhombotin family of cysteine-rich LIM-domain oncogenes : distinct members are involved in T-cell translocations to human chromosomes 11p15 and 11p13 .
A chromosomal translocation in a T-cell leukemia involving the short arm of human chromosome 11 at band 11p15 disrupts the <extra_id_0> rhombotin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .
This gene encodes a protein with duplicated cysteine-rich regions called LIM domains , which show homology to zinc - binding proteins and to iron-sulfur centers of ferredoxins .
Two homologues of the <extra_id_0> rhombotin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene have now been isolated .

One of these , designated <extra_id_0> Rhom-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is located on human chromosome 11 at band 11p13 , where a cluster of T-cell leukemia - specific translocations occur ; all translocation breakpoints at 11p13 are upstream of the <extra_id_0> Rhom-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .

Human and mouse <extra_id_0> Rhom-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are highly conserved and , like <extra_id_0> rhombotin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , encode two tandem cysteine-rich LIM domains .

<extra_id_0> Rhom-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA is expressed in early mouse development in central nervous system , lung , kidney , liver , and spleen but only very low levels occur in thymus .

The other gene , designated <extra_id_0> Rhom-3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is not on chromosome 11 but also retains homology to the LIM domain of <extra_id_0> rhombotin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Since the <extra_id_0> Rhom-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene is such a common site of chromosomal damage in T-cell tumors , the consistency of translocations near the <extra_id_0> rhombotin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene was further examined .
A second translocation adjacent to <extra_id_0> rhombotin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was found and at the same position as in the previous example .

Therefore , chromosome bands 11p15 ( <extra_id_0> rhombotin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and 11p13 ( <extra_id_0> Rhom-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) are consistent sites of chromosome translocation in T-cell leukemia , with the 11p15 target more rarely involved .
The results define the rhombotin gene family as a class of T-cell oncogenes with duplicated cysteine-rich LIM domains .
